title: Caustic Ingestion Injury
diagnosis_topic: Chemical injury to the esophagus and stomach after ingestion of corrosive agents
setup_script: “A 25-year-old woman presents after ingesting an unknown quantity of drain cleaner in a suicide attempt. She has odynophagia and drooling on arrival.”

dynamic_flow.reply: Patient has stridor and hoarseness. Edema appears to be progressing.
BP 115/75 mmHg, HR 105 bpm, RR 24/min, Temp 37.1°C.
Patient develops acute respiratory distress with worsening stridor.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident establishes IV access, keeps patient NPO, and administers IV fluids
If resident avoids inducing emesis or placing NG tube blindly
If resident orders chest and abdominal X-ray
If resident requests CT scan due to suspected perforation
dynamic_flow.reply: CT abdomen/pelvis shows no free perforation.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident arranges endoscopy within 12–24 hours
dynamic_flow.reply: Endoscopy shows mucosal injury graded by Zargar classification.
Patient managed with IV PPI, sucralfate, and gradual advancement of diet.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If injury is grade III or perforation present
If resident proceeds to operative management
dynamic_flow.reply: Ask resident to describe operative approach and key steps for esophagectomy or gastrectomy with mediastinal/abdominal drainage.
Psychiatric consultation performed for suicide risk.
Patient is counseled regarding surveillance for esophageal strictures and risk of squamous cell carcinoma.
Family instructed on safe storage of caustic substances and provided with poison control resources.

critical_decision_points: Avoidance of emesis or blind NG tube placement
Early endoscopic evaluation to grade mucosal injury
Ability to describe operative management in detail when indicated
Long-term surveillance for strictures and malignancy
